repnme.cdata!:
Jamaica - Program of Development Policy
            Loans for Fiscal Sustainability

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the First Programmatic
            Fiscal Sustainability Development Policy Loan Project (FSDPL
            I) for Jamaica were as follows: outcomes were moderately
            satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was
            substantial, the Bank performance was moderately
            satisfactory, and the Borrower performance was also
            moderately satisfactory. Some lessons learned included:
            coordination with other multilaterals and bilateral
            institutions enhances the impact of Bank operations. FSDPL I
            was part of a package of support for the Jamaica Debt
            Exchange (JDX) by International Financial Institutions
            (IFIs) and bilateral donors, and its impact was amplified by
            complementary programs by the International Monetary Fund
            (IMF) and the Inter-American Development Bank (IADB). Use of
            high level outcome indicators to measure progress can be
            problematic. Since this was an operation that was meant to
            enhance debt and fiscal sustainability, it made sense, a
            priori, to include quantitative measures such as the primary
            balance to gross domestic product (GDP) and debt to GDP. In
            hindsight, however, it was clear that these outcomes are
            well beyond the control of the Bank or the Government. The
            impact of the global crisis, the Supreme Court ruling on
            wages, and an early election on these indicators was
            something that was difficult to counter with the measures
            envisaged in the FSDPL series. The use of technical
            assistance and/or investment lending to bolster capacity can
            help achieve results on reforms. Including privatization of
            specific enterprises as an outcome indicator is problematic.

repnme.cdata!:
Jamaica - Second Programmatic Fiscal
            Sustainability Development Policy Loan Project : summary of discussion

abstracts.cdata!:
Executive Directors approved the Second
            Programmatic Fiscal Sustainability Development Policy Loan
            (FSDPL2) Project to Jamaica in the amount of US$100 million
            on the payment terms and conditions set out in the
            President's Memorandum (R2011-0194). Executive
            Directors expressed support for the DPL and the overall
            design of the program, and that its three main policy areas
            are an adequate foundation for the Government's
            long-term development strategy. Executive Directors observed
            that the DPL builds upon progress made under the previous
            operation and that the DPL's coverage of fiscal reforms
            is a key determinant of economic stability and a foundation
            for inclusive growth. Executive Directors also noted the
            delays in the IMF program and encouraged the Jamaican
            authorities to take steps to conclude the fourth and fifth
            reviews under the International Monetary Fund (IMF) Stand-By
            Arrangement. Executive Directors acknowledged the external
            and internal challenges that remain and encouraged further
            efforts by the authorities in improving fiscal and debt
            sustainability. They urged continued collaboration among
            development partners to ensure successful implementation of
            this project.

repnme.cdata!:
Jamaica - Second Programmatic Debt and
            Fiscal Sustainability Development Policy Loan Program

abstracts.cdata!:
The objectives of the Second
            Programmatic Debt and Fiscal Sustainability Development
            Policy Loan (FSDPL2) Program for Jamaica are enhancing
            fiscal and debt sustainability, by supporting reforms to
            increase control on public spending and debt generation,
            reduce debt service burden and improve debt management,
            reduce financial vulnerabilities, and increase public
            spending effectiveness; increasing the efficiency of
            financial management and budget processes, by supporting
            efforts to improve the efficiency of public expenditure and
            investment, and strengthen control of public finances and
            the effectiveness of government budgeting practices; and
            reducing distortions and enhancing the efficiency of the tax
            system, through reducing the use of fiscal incentives and
            increasing the uniformity of the tax code, improving client
            services for tax payers, broadening the tax base, and
            simplifying tax payments. This program document describes
            the single-tranche FSDPL2 in the amount of US$100 million
            for Jamaica. The operation builds on the progress made under
            the Bank's previous FSDPL and the FSDPL1, February
            2010. The reform program supported by the DPL is the
            manifestation of the Jamaican Government's strategy to
            increase fiscal and debt sustainability, improve
            macroeconomic stability, and accelerate growth. Reflecting
            the most pressing concerns at the time of operation
            preparation, the focus of the Government's program has
            been primarily on the first objective of fiscal and debt
            sustainability. However, the Government of Jamaica (GoJ) has
            made significant progress towards achievement of its
            objectives in each of these three areas, despite the
            difficult external environment and the slow pace of recovery
            from the adverse effects of the global crisis. The GoJ
            remains committed to its medium term reform program under a
            challenging environment. The GoJ recognizes the importance
            of improving macroeconomic stability and paving the way for
            accelerated growth while protecting the poor. The
            macroeconomic environment was strengthened substantially by
            the successful implementation of Government's reforms.
